posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked: Hello, I have been trying to get auton mirroring to work for the past week. Our problem is that the PathPlanner built in autonomous mirrorer changes our position correctly but not our rotation, causing our blue and red autons to both move in the same direction. We have tried flipping the heading by 180 degrees, offsetting the odometry by 180 degrees using SetAngleAdjustment, etc but they all don’t work. Is there something i’m missing here or am I just incompetent? Here is the code down below:

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: You should always be resetting your odometry so that 0 heading is facing toward the red alliance wall, no matter what side you’re on.

posts.name: Question all assumptions, search for truth.
posts.cooked:
We had these issues rhis year as well.   For us, we had to make a paradigm shift.  In previous years, the gyro was the source of truth for rotation heading.  We had to switch to the drive odometry being the source of truth, with the gyro being a constant input to the odometry.

So with the field always using blue origin, and always using the blue botpose from our limelight for April Tags, we set our drive odometry initially from any April Tag, and from then on can just give the odometry the gyro and vision update every loop.

Once you have that, odometry’s 0 degrees is always toward the red alliance wall from the blue alliance wall.

If you are using field oriented control, the last thing to change is to invert your lateral controls if you are on the red alliance since the driver is facing 180 degrees away from field zero.

Once we did that, pathplanner worked properly.
posts.display_username: Question all assumptions, search for truth.

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked: So what we should do is set odometry to 0 when on the blue alliance and 180 on the red alliance? (since robot is flipped around 180 when starting on red alliance) We are already offsetting the starting odometry by 180 degrees when starting on the red alliance.

posts.name: Question all assumptions, search for truth.
posts.cooked:
Since you are passing Pose2d to resetOdometry, I’m assuming you have a swerve drive.  You need to set the rotation of the Pose2d to whatever field-relative angle the robot is facing (so, yes, if it is facing downfield from the red alliance, this value would be 180 degrees or pi radians.)  That is how you would set your odometry.

You also need to pass in they gyro’s reading to resetOdometry, but you do not have to do ANY offsets.  The docstring for the resetOdometry method states:

The gyroscope angle does not need to be reset in the user’s robot code. The library automatically takes care of offsetting the gyro angle.

So, you give it the actual angle the robot is facing in the Pose2d object, and you give it the “raw” reading of the gyro and the library takes care of the offsets for every future update of the odometry.  You shouldn’t be messing with offsetting the reading of the gyro at all.
posts.display_username: Question all assumptions, search for truth.

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked: This suggestion fixed the translation issue (I think), but now the red auton is rotating to the end angle of the blue alliance auton (0 degrees) rather than the end angle of the red alliance auton (180 degrees).

reply_to_user.name: Question all assumptions, search for truth.

posts.name: Question all assumptions, search for truth.
posts.cooked: How are you assigning it’s initial pose?  What does the odomwtry say it’s angle is at the end of autonomous?  Maybe a link to your code would help.
posts.display_username: Question all assumptions, search for truth.

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked:
Initial pose is assigned by offsetting the PathPlanner starting pose by 180 if the alliance is red. All other poses are unchanged, though, which is the issue I am trying to figure out. I havent had a chance to test the odometry yet, as I’ve been testing the robot on a cart. Here is our code:

posts.name: Question all assumptions, search for truth.
posts.cooked: I’ll have to look at the code later, but you shouldn’t offset the angle when on red.  Pathplanner conforms to the blue end origin regardless of which alliance you are on.
posts.display_username: Question all assumptions, search for truth.

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked: Not offsetting the angle causes the robot’s starting pose on red to be the same as on blue, which is the problem because it will make the robot on red try to drive in the same direction as on blue (into the subwoofer). Offsetting the starting angle by 180 on red causes the robot to start and drive in the right orientation, but all the other rotation targets in the path are not offset. Is there any way to offset the rest of the rotation targets in the path?

reply_to_user.name: Question all assumptions, search for truth.
